channel.title: BBC News | UK | UK Edition
channel.description: Visit BBC News for up-to-the-minute news, breaking news, video, audio and feature stories. BBC News provides trusted World and UK news as well as local and regional perspectives. Also entertainment, business, science, technology and health news.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse

item.title: Nail-bomber given life sentence
item.description: A Muslim convert is jailed for life after launching a failed suicide bomb attack on a restaurant in Devon.

item.title: Refinery strikes spread across UK
item.description: Strikes break out across the UK in support of a walkout by energy workers against the use of foreign labour.

item.title: Man killed visiting newborn son
item.description: A man is stabbed to death in south London while travelling to hospital to visit his wife who had just given birth.

item.title: Honda's four-month shutdown to start
item.description: Staff at Honda in Swindon will work for the last day for four months on Friday as an extended shutdown takes effect.

item.title: Brown urges global 'confidence'
item.description: World leaders must have the "confidence to act" to deal with the global recession, Gordon Brown says in Davos.

item.title: Record number of inmates freed
item.description: A record number of prisoners have been were released early to ease prison overcrowding, new figures show.

item.title: Neighbour jailed for sword death
item.description: A London man is jailed for 11 years for killing his neighbour with a samurai sword in a row over a child's football.

item.title: Mortgage approvals rise slightly
item.description: The number of new mortgages approved for home buyers picked up slightly in December, but remains at historic lows.

item.title: Rapist's £5,000 jail toilet claim
item.description: A convicted paedophile claims £5,000 compensation because his prison cell does not have sanitation.

item.title: Personalised plates 1HRH and 1O auctioned for more than £320,000
item.description: Two personalised number plates - 1 HRH and 1 O - have been auctioned for a total of more than £320,000.

item.title: Abolish post of Poet Laureate - says the favourite for the job
item.description: Wendy Cope, a favourite to succeed Andrew Motion as Poet Laureate, calls for the post to be abolished.

item.title: Nolan completes Newcastle switch
item.description: Bolton midfielder Kevin Nolan joins Newcastle United for £4m on a four-and-a-half year contract.

item.title: Blackburn swoop for striker Diouf
item.description: Striker El-Hadji Diouf joins Blackburn from Sunderland for an undisclosed fee.

item.title: Robson reaches Aussie Open final
item.description: Britain's Laura Robson remains on track for her second junior Grand Slam title after beating Noppawan Lertcheewakarn to reach the Australian Open final.

item.title: Basra diary
item.description: All eyes focused on key provincial elections

item.title: Life after Honda
item.description: A laid-off car worker turns his hand to new skills

item.title: Nick Robinson
item.description: Why I said Lords police investigation 'will never happen'

item.title: Quiz of the week
item.description: Which of these ends up round the neck of a Lord?

item.title: City Diaries
item.description: The most boisterous people are now humble

item.title: Sounding foreign
item.description: Should Nazis be made to speak with English accents?

item.title: City must improve child services
item.description: The government gives Birmingham City Council 12 months to improve its children's services following 15 deaths in four years.

item.title: Man killed as 13 vehicles crash
item.description: A man dies and several other people are injured when 12 cars and a lorry crash on the A12 in Essex.

item.title: Surge expected for tax deadline
item.description: Taxpayers have been completing self-assessment tax returns in record numbers ahead of Saturday's deadline.

item.title: Legal threats over rape support
item.description: More than 100 councils face legal action for not providing specialist support services to women affected by sexual violence.

item.title: 'Unproductive' youths increase
item.description: A growing number of young people are not in work, education or training in England, figures suggest.

item.title: UK rejects massacre inquiry call
item.description: Britain has rejected demands for an inquiry into the massacre of Malaysian villagers by troops in 1948, the Foreign Office confirms.

item.title: Ferry passengers on dry land
item.description: Almost 200 passengers and crew who were trapped on a ferry by a jammed lorry are finally back on dry land.

item.title: Texting to ease the gloom
item.description: For those depressed by winter darkness, a new scheme which relies on text alerts could help.

item.title: Can't live with you...
item.description: Married, but not together. How does this work, asks Laurie Taylor in his weekly column for the Magazine.

item.title: $1m drop off
item.description: The story of how Somali pirates get their ransoms

item.title: Papers criticise Rhys sentences
item.description: Friday's papers report on the sentences handed to the accomplices of Rhys Jones' killers

item.title: Policeman cleared of beating wife
item.description: A former police officer accused of beating up his wife after discovering she was having an affair is cleared of assault.

item.title: Hospital sorry over stolen laptop
item.description: A leading children's hospital apologises after a laptop containing information on hundreds of young patients is stolen.

item.title: Council fined £40,000 after death
item.description: Belfast City Council is fined £40,000 after a man dies at its Dargan Road landfill site in north Belfast.

item.title: Two held as investigation reopens
item.description: Two people are arrested in connection with the deaths of a man and a woman in Castlerock in 1991.

item.title: Energy protest grows in Scotland
item.description: More than 1,500 workers in Scotland are on strike as part of an escalating UK-wide dispute over the use of foreign labour.

item.title: 'Candid' driver says 'I'm drunk'
item.description: A man who crashed his car told police there was no point asking what had happened because he was drunk, a court hears.

item.title: Support demo over foreign staff
item.description: A 'peaceful protest' is taking place outside a Welsh power station over the use of foreign workers at oil refineries in the UK.

item.title: Women 'transform Welsh politics'
item.description: A high representation of women AMs in the Welsh assembly has an effect on the way politics is conducted, research shows.
